stem: A mother complains that her 4-year-old daughter's urine smells strange. Her urine dipstick is positive for leukocytes and nitrates but negative for blood. The most likely causative agent is
disc:
This question aims to assess the knowledge of the epidemiology of pediatric urinary tract infections.

E. coli is the most common organism found in children with urinary tract infections accounting for up to 80% of the cases. In addition, Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter can also cause UTIs. Infection with E. coli has a higher risk of renal scarring as well.

Viruses and fungi are uncommon causes of UTIs in children.
